{{History of Japan |image=Shoso-in.jpg |caption=[[Shōsōin]]}} {{nihongo|'''Kenryaku'''|建暦|}} was a {{nihongo|[[Japanese era name]]|年号,|''nengō'',|lit. "year name"}} after ''[[Jōgen (Kamakura period)|Jōgen]]'' and before ''[[Kempo (era)|Kempo]].'' This period spanned the years from March 1211 through December 1213.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "''Kenryaku''" in [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA510&dq= ''Japan encyclopedia'', p. 510;] n.b., Louis-Frédéric is pseudonym of Louis-Frédéric Nussbaum, ''see'' [http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 Deutsche Nationalbibliothek Authority File] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120524174828/http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 |date=2012-05-24 }}. The reigning emperor was {{nihongo|[[Emperor Juntoku|Juntoku]]''-tennō''|順徳天皇}}.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). ''Annales des empereurs du Japon'', pp. 230-238; Brown, Delmer ''et al.'' (1979). ''Gukanshō'', pp. 341-343; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). ''Jinnō Shōtōki.'' pp. 221-223. ==Change of era== * '''1211''' {{nihongo|''Kenryaku gannen''|建暦元年}}: The new era name was created because the previous era ended and a new one commenced in ''Jōgen'' 2, on the 9th day of the 3rd month of 1211.Brown, p. 341. ==Events of the ''Kenryaku'' era== * '''1211''' (''Kenryaku 1, 1st month''): Shōgun Sanetomo's position at court was raised to the 1st rank of the 3rd class.Titsingh, p. 230. [[File:Sennyuji.jpg|thumb|right|Sennyū-ji established in 1211]] * '''1211''' (''Kenryaku 1, 1st month''): The Buddhist priest [[Hōnen]] returned to Kyoto from a period of exile. He was the founder and guiding force behind the early development of the {{nihongo|[[Sennyū-ji]]|泉涌寺,|Sennyū-ji}} temple-complex. * '''January 12, 1212''' (''Kenryaku 2, 20th day of the 12th month''): The Buddhist priest [[Hōnen]] died at age 80, mere days after drafted a brief, written summary of his life teachings. This last written document is known as the [[One-Sheet Document]] (''ichimai-kishomon'').Titsigh, p. 231; [http://www.jodo.org/teachings/teachings02.html Jodo Shu web site] * '''1212''' (''Kenryaku 2, 16th day of the 1st month''): The former-Senior High Priest Jien (1155–1225) was appointed Tendai Abbot by Imperial Mandate. He would administer Mt. Hiei for one year before yielding the position on the 11th day of the 1st month of 1213.Brown, p. 342. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Brown, Delmer and Ichiro Ishida. (1979). ''The Future and the Past: a translation and study of the 'Gukanshō', an interpretative history of Japan written in 1219.'' Berkeley: [[University of California Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-520-03460-0}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/future-and-the-past-a-translation-and-study-of-the-gukansho-an-interpretative-history-of-japan-written-in-1219/oclc/5145872&referer=brief_results OCLC 5145872] * Kitagawa, Hiroshi and Bruce T. Tsuchida, eds. (1975). ''[[The Tale of the Heike]].'' Tokyo: [[University of Tokyo Press]]. {{ISBN|9784130870245}}; {{ISBN|9784130870238}}; {{ISBN|9780860081883}}; {{ISBN|9780860081890}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/tale-of-the-heike-heike-monogatari/oclc/193064639?referer=di&ht=edition OCLC 193064639] * Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&client=firefox-a ''Japan encyclopedia.''] Cambridge: [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-674-01753-5}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/58053128?referer=di&ht=edition OCLC 58053128] * [[Isaac Titsingh|Titsingh, Isaac.]] (1834). ''[[Nihon Odai Ichiran]]''; ou, [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&dq=nipon+o+dai+itsi+ran ''Annales des empereurs du Japon.''] Paris: Royal Asiatic Society, Oriental Translation Fund of Great Britain and Ireland. [http://www.worldcat.org/title/nipon-o-dai-itsi-ran-ou-annales-des-empereurs-du-japon/oclc/5850691 OCLC 5850691] * [[H. Paul Varley|Varley, H. Paul]]. (1980). ''A Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns: Jinnō Shōtōki of Kitabatake Chikafusa.'' New York: [[Columbia University Press]]. {{ISBN|9780231049405}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/chronicle-of-gods-and-sovereigns-jinno-shotoki-of-kitabatake-chikafusa/oclc/6042764&referer=brief_results OCLC 6042764] ==External links== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" [http://www.ndl.go.jp/koyomi/e/ -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before =[[Jōgen (Kamakura period)|Jōgen]] | title = [[Japanese era name|Era or ''nengō'']]

'''Pennsylvania firsts''' is a list of firsts in the colony and [[Commonwealth of Pennsylvania]], and in the city of [[Philadelphia]].
== Firsts == ===17th Century=== * 1688 — First public protest of slavery in America, [[Germantown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Germantown]], (now part of Philadelphia)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/chr_slav3.htm |title=Christianity and Slavery |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> ===18th Century=== * 1731 — First subscription library, [[Library Company of Philadelphia]], founded by [[Benjamin Franklin]]<ref name=instance>{{cite book |url=http://www.librarycompany.org/about/Instance.pdf |title=At the Instance of Benjamin Franklin: A Brief History of the Library Company of Philadelphia |first=Edwin |last=Wolf |publisher=The Library Company of Philadelphia |location=Philadelphia |year=1976 |isbn=0-914076-73-6}}</ref> * 1732 — First social club in the English-speaking world, the [[Schuylkill Fishing Company]] of the State in Schuylkill, Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|author=[ Displaying Abstract ] |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9907E6D6173AE733A25756C1A9679C946497D6CF |title=''The New York Times'': "Oldest Dining Club in the World" (January 15, 1905) |publisher=New York Times |date=2012-06-10 |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1743 — First institution devoted to science, the [[American Philosophical Society]], Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amphilsoc.org/about/ |title=American Philosophical Society |publisher=Amphilsoc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1748 — First dancing organization in America, the Philadelphia Dancing Assemblies * 1748 — First Lutheran church body in North America, the [[Pennsylvania Ministerium]]<ref>[[Eric W. Gritsch]], ''A History of Lutheranism,'' (Minneapolis:Fortress Press, 2002) p.175.</ref> * 1751 — First hospital in America, the [[Pennsylvania Hospital]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pennmedicine.org/about | title=About Penn Medicine: History | publisher=Penn Medicine | accessdate=December 5, 2017}}</ref> * 1754 — First (and only){{Failed verification|date=January 2011}} surrender by [[George Washington]], [[Fort Necessity]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mountvernon.org/learn/meet_george/index.cfm/ss/21/ |title=George Washington biography |publisher=Mountvernon.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823160852/http://www.mountvernon.org/learn/meet_george/index.cfm/ss/21 |archivedate=2011-08-23 |df= }}</ref> * 1755 — Continental Marines founded, [[Tun Tavern]], Philadelphia; now known as [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmcpress.com/heritage/usmc_heritage.htm |title=USMC Heritage |publisher=Usmcpress.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1762 — First lectures on [[anatomy]] in North America, Dr. [[William Shippen]], Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/1700s/people/shippen_wm_jr.html |title=William Shippen, Jr. (1736-1808)|accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704132744/http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/1700s/people/shippen_wm_jr.html |archivedate=July 4, 2008 }}</ref> * 1765 — First medical school, Penn's Medical School (now [[The University of Pennsylvania]]), which made Penn the first educational institution to become a university in the United States, Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/1700s/people/morgan_john.html |title=John Morgan (1735-1789)|accessdate=April 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703234451/http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/1700s/people/morgan_john.html |archivedate=July 3, 2008 }}</ref> * 1766 — First organized hunting club in America, the Gloucester Fox Hunting Club near Philadelphia * 1774 — First continuously serving unit in the United States military, the [[First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry]] * 1777 — First United States Capital, [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]]. Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was the first capital under the First Continental Congress from September 5, 1774 to October 24, 1774. Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was the first capital under the Articles of Confederation from March 1, 1781 to June 21, 1783<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.med.upenn.edu/globalhealth/documents/WebVersionPhila122004.pdf|format=PDF|title=CITY OF PHILADELPHIA|publisher=Med.upenn.edu|accessdate=2015-02-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706113852/http://www.med.upenn.edu/globalhealth/documents/WebVersionPhila122004.pdf|archivedate=2015-07-06|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Cecil Adams |url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/041210.html |title=York, Pennsylvania: First capital of the United States? |publisher=The Straight Dope |date=2004-12-10 |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1780 — First abolition law, while the state capital was in Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/states/statutes/pennst01.htm |title=An Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery.(1)|accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080923005852/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/states/statutes/pennst01.htm |archivedate=September 23, 2008 }}</ref> * 1784 — First successful daily newspaper, ''[[Pennsylvania Packet|The Pennsylvania Packet and Daily Advertiser]]'', Philadelphia<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://media.experiencepa.com/firsts.aspx?site=ExperiencePA] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060911124951/http://media.experiencepa.com/firsts.aspx?site=ExperiencePA |date=September 11, 2006 }}</ref> * 1786 — First vessel ever moved by steam, [[Delaware River]] at Philadelphia, by [[John Fitch (inventor)|John Fitch]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.rochester.edu/steam/westcott/ |title=Life of John Fitch : the inventor of the steam-boat|accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110913042825/http://www.history.rochester.edu/steam/westcott/ |archivedate=September 13, 2011 }}</ref> * 1790 — First stock exchange in America, Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phlx.com/Exchange/history.html|title=Page Not Available|publisher=Phlx.com|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> * 1792 — First [[United States Mint]], Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushistory.org/tour/tour_mint.htm |title=U.S. Mint |publisher=Ushistory.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1794 — First African Methodist Episcopal church, [[Mother Bethel A.M.E. Church]], Philadelphia<ref>[http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/548/The_First_African_Methodist_Episcopal_Church_founded] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104082954/http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/548/The_First_African_Methodist_Episcopal_Church_founded |date=January 4, 2006 }}</ref> * 1795 — First [[Toll road|turnpike]] in the United States, [[Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike]]<ref name=autogenerated1 /> * 1796 — First [[suspension bridge]], [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania|Uniontown]] by [[James Finley (engineer)|James Finley]]<ref name=bridge>{{cite web|url=http://www.icomos.org/studies/bridges.htm#13 |title=Context for World Heritage Bridges|accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109015509/http://www.icomos.org/studies/bridges.htm |archivedate=January 9, 2012 }}</ref>
===19th Century=== * 1805 — First art institution in America, the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]], Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pafa.org/archive.jsp |title=Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts| accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509091626/http://www.pafa.org/archive.jsp |archivedate=May 9, 2008 }}</ref> * 1805 — First covered bridge in America, the [[Market Street Bridge (Philadelphia)|Market Street Bridge]] (a.k.a. "the Permanent Bridge"), Philadelphia * 1809 — First theater in America, the Walnut Street Theatre, Philadelphia * 1816 — First wire cable suspension bridge, near Philadelphia, by [[Josiah White]] and [[Erskine Hazard]]<ref name=bridge /> * 1821 — First Pharmacy school, [[Philadelphia College of Pharmacy]] (now part of the [[University of the Sciences in Philadelphia]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usip.edu/aboutUSP/ |title=About USP |publisher=Usip.edu |date=2010-10-04 |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1845 — First T-rail rolled in United States, [[Danville, Pennsylvania|Danville]] * 1848 — First and only visual arts college for women in the United States, [[Moore College of Art & Design]], Philadelphia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moore.edu/about-moore/mission-history|title=Moore College of Art & Design – Mission & History|website=moore.edu}}</ref> * 1856 — First national convention for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], [[Musical Fund Hall]], [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] * 1859 — First grand opera house in the United States still used for its original purpose, the Academy of Music, Philadelphia * 1859 — First successful oil well, [[Titusville, Pennsylvania|Titusville]] ([[Edwin L. Drake]])<ref name="WDL">{{cite web |url = http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11368/ |title = Titusville, Pennsylvania, 1896 |website = [[World Digital Library]] |date = 1896 |accessdate = 2013-07-16 }}</ref> * 1861 — First pretzel factory, [[Sturgis Pretzel House|Julius Sturgis]], [[Lititz, Pennsylvania|Lititz]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albright.edu/reporter/fall01/sturgis01.html |title=Sturgis Pretzel House |publisher=Albright.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * 1862 — First [[American Civil War|Civil War]] battle north of the [[Mason–Dixon line]], [[Hanover, Pennsylvania|Hanover]], [[J.E.B. page.title: List of rulers of the Yoruba state of Sabe

revision.text:
Sabe is a territory located in present-day [[Benin]], based in and around the town of [[Savé]]
In the [[Yoruba language]], the word [[Oba (king)|Oba]] means '''king''' or '''ruler'''. It is also common for the obas of the various [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] domains to have their own special titles. In '''Sabe''' the Oba is referred to as the '''Onisabe of Sabe'''
Records for Sabe are fragmentary and conflicting, containing a long succession of rulers styled ''Ola''. It is suggested by one source that recent rulers alternate between descendants of either of two brothers.
The list presented here represents a fragment of the record.
==List of Rulers of the Yoruba state of Sabe==

{{Year nav topic5|{{CURRENTYEAR}}|the environment}} This is a '''list of years in the environment'''. The subjects relate to [[environmental law]], [[conservation (ethic)|conservation]], [[environmentalism]] and [[environmental issue]]s.
:''Some of the more notable events are listed here with a full list on the respective pages.'' {{TOC right}}
==List of years==
===1970s=== *[[1970 in the environment|1970]] *[[1971 in the environment|1971]] *[[1972 in the environment|1972]] - ''[[The Limits to Growth]]'' was published. The book is about the computer modelling of unchecked economic and population growth with finite resource supplies, and became both controversial and influential. *[[1973 in the environment|1973]] *[[1974 in the environment|1974]] *[[1975 in the environment|1975]] *[[1976 in the environment|1976]] - Ongoing oil spills began in Nigeria leading to various [[environmental issues in the Niger Delta]]. *[[1977 in the environment|1977]] *[[1978 in the environment|1978]] - The [[Amoco Cadiz oil spill|''Amoco Cadiz'' oil spill]] occurred on the coast of Brittany resulting in the largest oil spill of its kind in history to that date. *[[1979 in the environment|1979]] - The [[Three Mile Island accident]], a partial nuclear meltdown that released radioactive material, occurred in the United States.
===1980s=== *[[1980 in the environment|1980]] *[[1981 in the environment|1981]] *[[1982 in the environment|1982]] *[[1983 in the environment|1983]] *[[1984 in the environment|1984]] *[[1985 in the environment|1985]] - the [[International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1983|International Tropical Timber Agreement]] enters into force. *[[1986 in the environment|1986]] - the [[Chernobyl disaster]], a catastrophic nuclear accident, occurred at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine *[[1987 in the environment|1987]] *[[1988 in the environment|1988]] - the [[Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer]] enters into force. *[[1989 in the environment|1989]] - the [[Exxon Valdez oil spill|''Exxon Valdez'' oil spill]] occurred in Prince William Sound, Alaska.
===1990s=== *[[1990 in the environment|1990]] *[[1991 in the environment|1991]] *[[1992 in the environment|1992]] *[[1993 in the environment|1993]] - the [[Convention on Biological Diversity]], known informally as the Biodiversity Convention, enters into force. It is an international legally binding treaty. *[[1994 in the environment|1994]] - the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) enters into force. *[[1995 in the environment|1995]] *[[1996 in the environment|1996]] *[[1997 in the environment|1997]] *[[1998 in the environment|1998]] *[[1999 in the environment|1999]]
===2000s=== *[[2000 in the environment|2000]] *[[2001 in the environment|2001]] *[[2002 in the environment|2002]] - the World Summit on Sustainable Development, WSSD or [[Earth Summit 2002]] took place in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 26 August to 4 September 2002. It was convened to discuss sustainable development by the United Nations. *[[2003 in the environment|2003]] *[[2004 in the environment|2004]] *[[2005 in the environment|2005]] *[[2006 in the environment|2006]] *[[2007 in the environment|2007]] *[[2008 in the environment|2008]] *[[2009 in the environment|2009]]
===2010s=== *[[2010 in the environment|2010]] :: - 2010 is declared to be the [[International Year of Biodiversity]] by the United Nations General Assembly. :: - The [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|''Deepwater Horizon'' oil spill]] in the Gulf of Mexico flows unabated for three months. *[[2011 in the environment|2011]] - 2011 was declared the [[International Year of Forests]] by the United Nations *[[2012 in the environment|2012]] *[[2013 in the environment|2013]] *[[2014 in the environment|2014]]
==See also== *[[Timeline of environmental history]] *[[Timeline of the history of environmentalism]]
